title: qraLm
text: can install qraLm GitHub: https://github.com/vcadavez/qraLm using devtools package, R code . must first install doseresponsemodels package github: https://github.com/vcadavez/doseresponsemodels, implements dose-response models Listeria monocytogenes. Windows users recommended install Rtools: https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/Rtools/ . packages qraLm depends : Hmisc, extraDistr, mc2d, matrixStats, DT, dplyr, ggplot2, plotly, doseresponsemodels BH; install installing qraLm.

what: Dose-response model function for the qraLm models — DRForModel
title: Dose-response model function for the qraLm models — DRForModel
text: function provides marginal probability invasive listeriosis given population given Dose CFU using JEMRA, Pouillot, Fritsch EFSA dose-response models model developed within project (EFSAMV,EFSAV,EFSALV) (see References).

title: Dose-response model function for the qraLm models — DRForModel
code: DRForModel(data = list(), model = "JEMRA", population = 1, Poisson = FALSE)

title: Dose-response model function for the qraLm models — DRForModel
text: data list (minima): N (CFU) matrix containing numbers L. monocytogenes per portion defrosted frozen vegetables. model either JEMRA, Pouillot, Fritsch, EFSA, EFSAMV,EFSAV EFSALV population considered population (scalar). Poisson TRUE, assume Dose mean Poisson distribution. (actual LogNormal Poisson). FALSE (default), assume Dose actual number bacteria.

title: Dose-response model function for the qraLm models — DRForModel
text: data object added: Risk matrix risk, size similar N Model Model Population Population

title: Dose-response model function for the qraLm models — DRForModel
text: see doseresponsemodels::DR() doseresponsemodels::DRQuick() details population models.

title: Dose-response model function for the qraLm models — DRForModel
text: function uses (model JEMRA) linear approximation (approxfun) exact doseresponsemodels::DR() model evaluated \(Dose = c(0,10^{seq(-5,12,length=1701)})\) (Poisson=TRUE) \(c(0,10^{seq(0,12,length=2000)})\) (Poisson=FALSE). Dose lower higher ranges lead NA.

what: Generation of contaminated lots with variability in prevalence and concentration — Lot2LotGen
title: Generation of contaminated lots with variability in prevalence and concentration — Lot2LotGen
text: function Lot2LotGen() generates matrix contaminated lots information parameters beta distribution (alpha, beta) representing -lot variability prevalence; parameters normal distribution (mean, sd) representing total variability microbial concentration contaminated units (log10 CFU/g); proportion total variance assigned -lot variance. Every row matrix corresponds production lot, broken units portions, columns matrix.

title: Generation of contaminated lots with variability in prevalence and concentration — Lot2LotGen
code: Lot2LotGen(   nLots,   sizeLot,   unitSize,   betaAlpha,   betaBeta,   C0MeanLog,   C0SdLog,   propVarInter,   Poisson = FALSE,   ... )

title: Generation of contaminated lots with variability in prevalence and concentration — Lot2LotGen
text: nLots Number lots sampled size Monte Carlo simulation (scalar). sizeLot Number units portions produced lot (scalar). unitSize Weight (g) single unit portion lot (scalar). betaAlpha Parameter alpha beta distribution representing -batch variability prevalence (scalar). betaBeta Parameter beta beta distribution representing -batch variability prevalence (scalar). C0MeanLog Mean parameter (log10 CFU/g) normal distribution representing total variability microbial concentration contaminated units (scalar vector). C0SdLog Standard deviation parameter (log10 CFU/g) normal distribution representing total variability microbial concentration contaminated units (scalar vector). propVarInter proportion total variance (\(C0\_sdLog10^2\)) attributed -lot variance. remaining (1-propVarInter) proportion within-lot variance. Poisson need defined

title: Generation of contaminated lots with variability in prevalence and concentration — Lot2LotGen
text: list four elements: N (CFU) matrix size nLots lots sizeLot units representing microbial numbers units portions contaminated lots; ProbUnitPos Probability lot contaminated (lot considered contaminated least one unit portion contaminated) (vector); P Mean prevalence contaminated lots (scalar); betaGen True prevalence contaminated units lots (sampled beta distribution) (vector).

title: Generation of contaminated lots with variability in prevalence and concentration — Lot2LotGen
text: function requires variability prevalence L. monocytogenes lots represented beta distribution. determine parameters beta distribution, beta-binomial distribution fitted survey data (compiled Table 3.21 (2022) , consisting positive samples total sample size. beta-binomial fitted Markov-Chain Monte Carlo approach, gamma(0.01, 0.01) priors parameters, assuming every data source (published paper) represents different lot. parameters beta distribution determined : betaAlpha=0.5112 betaBeta=9.959. mean (C0MeanLog=1.023 log10 CFU/g) standard deviation (C0SdLog=0.3267 log10\ CFU/g) normal distribution representing overall variability L. monocytogenes obtained using data Jeyaletchumi (2011)  (3.0 MPN/g, 3.6 MPN/g freshly harvested vegetables), Magdovitz et al. (2021)  (21, 36 75 MPN/g corn peas arriving frozen food facility), Kuan et al. (2017)  (3.0 MPN/g bulk carrots retail). algorithm decomposes log10 level total variance concentration -lot variance within-lot variance according proportion propVarInter.

what: Dicing of cantaloupe for preparation of RTE pre-cut cantaloupe — caDicing
title: Dicing of cantaloupe for preparation of RTE pre-cut cantaloupe — caDicing
text: function caDicing() simulates transfer L. monocytogenes rind flesh dicing cantaloupe processing environment. assumed every cantaloupe separately diced, contaminated rind, fraction L. monocytogenes cells transferred dices. Notice function consider cross-contamination dicing machine knives. transfer rate (TR) % (CFU/g dices per \(CFU/cm^2\ rind)*100\) modelled Pert distribution parameters minTR, modeTR maxTR.

title: Dicing of cantaloupe for preparation of RTE pre-cut cantaloupe — caDicing
code: caDicing(   data = list(),   minTR = 0.087,   modeTR = 0.55,   maxTR = 2.82,   cantaSurface = 580,   pulpYield = 0.6,   cantaWeight = NULL,   nLots = NULL,   sizeLot = NULL,   sizeSublot = 20 )

what: Cantaloupe washing in flume tank — caFlumeTank
title: Cantaloupe washing in flume tank — caFlumeTank
text: function caFlumeTank() simulates three events taking place flume tank washing: washing bacteria cantaloupe rind washing efficiency logDecWash; elimination bacteria sanitising water sanitising efficiency log10SaniWash; redistribution survivors cantaloupe rind.

what: Cantaloupe cross-contamination during washing in flume tank — caFlumeTankCC
title: Cantaloupe cross-contamination during washing in flume tank — caFlumeTankCC
text: function caFlumeTankCC() function simulates potential contamination cantaloupe, direct contact contaminated water flume tank. cross-contamination algorithm accounts four possible scenarios: cross-contamination occurring lots already contaminated; re-contamination occurring lots contaminated; cross-contamination occurring lots already contaminated; cross-contamination occurring lots contaminated.

title: Holding time of cantaloupes post-harvest — caHoldingTime
text: Data survival L. monocytogenes intact rind two varieties cantaloupe stored 4, 10 25 \(^\circ\) C extracted Nyarko et al. (2016) . non-linear mixed model based two-parameter Weibull decay equation random effects melon variety showed time achieve first log10 reduction (D) 25 \(^\circ\) C significantly different two temperatures, significant difference D storage temperatures 4 10 \(^\circ C\). Therefore, non-linear mixed model refitted two temperature classes (cool 4/10 \(^\circ C\)) ambient (25 \(^\circ C\)). shape parameter fixed two temperature classes. Placing random effects D cantaloupe variety clustering variable, estimates  meanD410, sdD410, meanD25 sdD25 obtained. present function represents cultivar-specific variability D cool ambient temperature normal distribution; D value sampled every lot, assuming different cantaloupe cultivar. assumed holding time, possible contaminated lot become free L. monocytogenes. Therefore, chance rinds cantaloupes contaminated lot end zero counts, one cell assigned one cantaloupe lot.

what: Cross-contamination of cantaloupe during dicing and partitioning into packed units — caPartitioningCC
title: Cross-contamination of cantaloupe during dicing and partitioning into packed units — caPartitioningCC
text: caPartitioningCC() function simulates potential cross-contamination cantaloupes, direct contact dicing machine knives, followed partitioning dices produced one processing lot (sublot) packed units. cross-contamination algorithm accounts four possible scenarios: cross-contamination occurring sublots already contaminated; contamination occurring sublots contaminated; cross-contamination occurring sublots already contaminated; cross-contamination occurring sublots contaminated. Probabilities occurrence every event computed. partitioning algorithm randomly distributes total numbers cells contaminated sublot dices packed units. dispersion factor b, parameter beta distribution, indicates extent cell clustering bulk dices sublot, ultimately heterogeneity number cells distributed among pack units.

title: Cross-contamination of cantaloupe during dicing and partitioning into packed units — caPartitioningCC

what: Contamination of cantaloupe rind from soil and irrigation water — caPrimaryProduction
title: Contamination of cantaloupe rind from soil and irrigation water — caPrimaryProduction
text: caPrimaryProduction() function assesses contamination cantaloupes soil irrigation water. considers soil water contamination characteristics prevalence (pSoil pIrrig) distributions L. monocytogenes concentration soil (cSoilLogMin, cSoilLogMode cSoilLogMax water (cIrrigLogMin cIrrigLogMax) inputs. pSoil pIrrig chosen user according existing data prevalence; whereas pSoil conditional several risk factors. identified risk factors ((2022) ) : irrigation previous days harvesting; use organic fertilizer affect pSoil associated odds-ratios (F_irrig_rain fManure). context, user define proportion fields practicing irrigation prior harvest undergoing rain (p_irrig_rain), proportion fields using organic amendments (pManure). what: Application of a testing regime for L. monocytogenes in a sample of RTE cantaloupe from a lot/sublot — caTesting
title: Application of a testing regime for L. monocytogenes in a sample of RTE cantaloupe from a lot/sublot — caTesting
text: caTesting() function function simulates microbiological testing food unit samples taken lot. Lots subjected, given probability (pLotTested), sampling testing, according sampling plan defined user. algorithm allows two-class three-class sampling plans, although commonly used L. monocytogenes former one: n (sample size), c (maximum level accepted), w (weight used enrichment essay). performing bootstrapping sampling testing scheme, algorithm estimates probability detecting contaminated lots. Contaminated lots detected testing removed matrix. input matrix sublot arrangement, size sublot (sizeSublot) must provided, testing carried lot level (sublot level!). Furthermore, user option output matrix N returned original lot arrangement setting backToSublot = FALSE. value assigned argument, output matrix N returned sublot arrangement.

title: Application of a testing regime for L. monocytogenes in a sample of RTE cantaloupe from a lot/sublot — caTesting

MTested (CFU/g) Maximum concentration accepted sample (scalar vector). \(>0\), lead 3-class plan. cTested Maximum number samples accepted \(m = 0\) M (scalar vector). pLotTested Proportion lots subjected sampling testing frequency testing (scalar vector). Se Sensibility test probability detect bacterial cell applying given microbiological essay (scalar vector). unitSize (g) Weight contents pack unit (scalar vector). gTestedEnum (g) Sample weight tested enumeration (scalar vector). sizeLot Total number cantaloupes making lot, .e., cantaloupes harvested field batch. sizeSublot Number cantaloupes processed sublot. sizeSublot must multiple sizeLot. title: Application of a testing regime for L. monocytogenes in a sample of food units from a lot — fvTesting
text: fvTesting() function simulates microbiological testing food unit samples taken lot. Lots subjected, given probability (pLotTested), sampling testing, according sampling plan defined user. algorithm allows two-class three-class sampling plans, although commonly used L. monocytogenes former one: n (sample size), c (maximum level accepted), w (weight used enrichment essay). performing bootstrapping sampling testing scheme, algorithm estimates probability detecting contaminated lots, probability individual lots contaminated given detected positive testing. title: Internal contamination of fish fillets during brine injection — sfBriningCC
text: function sfBriningCC() simulates potential internal contamination fish fillets brining injection salt solution. cross-contamination algorithm accounts four possible scenarios: cross-contamination occurring lots already contaminated; cross-contamination occurring lots contaminated; additional contamination occurring lots already contaminated; cross-contamination occurring lots contaminated. Probabilities occurrence four events computed. mean volume brine injected per fillet (V_inj) mean concentration L. monocytogenes brine (N_brine) allowed vary lot lot; , effect, values sampled Pert distributions parameters volInjMin, volInjMode, volInjMax; concBrineMin, concBrineMode, concBrineMax, respectively. estimate number cells transferred fish fillet, assumed cells follow Poisson distribution volume brine.

what: Cold chain logistics for ready-to-eat seafood — sfColdChain
title: Cold chain logistics for ready-to-eat seafood — sfColdChain
text: function sfColdChain() simulates growth L. monocytogenes, affected lactic acid bacteria (LAB) populations, RTE seafood various stages cold chain logistics, including transportation retail, display retail transportation home; relies growth kinetic functions sfMejlholmDalgaard, sfMejlholmDalgaardLAB() sfGrowthJameson(). function sfColdChain() can used home storage well, changing parameters defining time temperature Pert distributions. every lot, algorithm samples time temperature Pert distributions defined parameters timeMin, timeMode, timeMax, tempMin, tempMode, tempMax, respectively, provided user. specific growth rates L. monocytogenes LAB determined evaluating intrinsic extrinsic characteristics seafood product (sampled function sfCharacteristics()) Mejholm Daalgard's existing secondary models bacterial groups ((Mejlholm Dalgaard 2009) , (Mejlholm et al. 2010) , (Mejlholm Dalgaard 2013)  (Mejlholm Dalgaard 2015) ). parameters two growth rate models related reference growth rate, temperature, water activity, pH concentrations phenol, nitrites, CO2 equilibrium, undissociated lactic acid, undissociated diacetate, undissociated acetic acid, undissociated benzoic acid, undissociated citric undissociated sorbic acid, L. monocytogenes lactic acid bacteria, set default fitted validated Mejlholm et al. (2010)  Mejlholm Dalgaard (2013) , respectively. However, parameters growth rate models can altered updated. numbers L. monocytogenes RTE seafood product, affected LAB, estimated applying extended Jameson-effect competition model published Giménez Dalgaard (2004)  using interaction gamma parameter proposed Møller et al. (2013) .

text: function can used multiple times. microbial kinetic parameters MPD ln_q0 L. monocytogenes LAB sampled . Information building variability distributions retail time temperature obtained Pouillot et al. (2007)  FDA-FSIS (2003) . Home storage, Pert distribution temperature can defined using following parameters: tempMin = qnorm(0.025, 7, 3), tempMode = 7, tempMax = qnorm(0.975, 7, 3), reformulated normal(7.0, 3.0) used Pouillot et al. (2007) . Pert distribution home storage time can defined using following parameters: timeMin = qweibull(0.025,shape = 1.14, scale = 18.39) * 24 timeMode = 18.39*((1.14-1)/1.14)^(1/1.14) * 24 timeMax = qweibull(0.975,shape = 1.14, scale = 18.39) * 24 reformulated Weibull(1.14, 18.39) days used Endrikat et al. (2010) .

code: sfGrowthJameson(   time,   N0Lm,   N0LAB,   q0Lm,   q0LAB,   muLm,   muLAB,   MPDLm,   MPDLAB,   unitSize,   gamma = 1,   lim = 1,   step = 1 )

title: Growth model of L. monocytogenes in RTE seafood including background flora competition — sfGrowthJameson
text: time (h) Storage time pack RTE seafood N0Lm (CFU) Numbers L. monocytogenes RTE seafood time=0 N0LAB (CFU) Numbers LAB RTE seafood time=0 q0Lm Initial parameter Q Baranyi Roberts' model related lag phase L. monocytogenes time=0 q0LAB Initial parameter Q Baranyi Roberts' model related lag phase LAB time=0 muLm (h-1) Growth rate L. monocytogenes RTE seafood muLAB (h-1) Growth rate LAB RTE seafood MPDLm (log10 CFU/g) Maximum population density L. monocytogenes RTE seafood MPDLAB (log10 CFU/g) Maximum population density LAB RTE seafood unitSize (g) Weight contents RTE seafood pack (MPD) gamma Interaction parameter competition model. Note: gamma=1, population 1 stops population 2 reaches MPD. gamma < 1, population 1 still increases population 2 reaches MPD. gamma > 1, population 1 decreases population 2 reaches MPD. lim = 1 parameter indicating competition considered meaningful. step = 1 Integration step.

title: Growth of L. monocytogenes in raw fish — sfGrowthLPD
code: dat <- Lot2LotGen(   nLots = 100,   sizeLot = 100,   unitSize = 500,   betaAlpha = 0.5112,   betaBeta = 9.959,   C0MeanLog = 1.023,   C0SdLog = 0.3267,   propVarInter = 0.7 ) N <- matrix(1:12, ncol = 4, nrow = 3) dat <- list(N = N, unitSize = 500)  # Example of the first stage growth is taking place aLM <- 0.0581 # parameter for mu (h-1) Tmin <- 1.3 # parameter for mu (h-1) ALM <- 0.84 # parameter for LPD (h) mLM <- 1.11 # parameter for LPD (h) MPD <- 9.2 # log10CFU/g # value taken from Jia et al. (2020) time <- 11 Temp <- 2  first <- sfGrowthLPD(dat,   MPD = MPD,   Temp = 15,   time = 11 )  # Example with previous stage where growth took place second <- sfGrowthLPD(dat,   MPD = MPD,   Temp = 23,   time = 11,   workDone = first$workDone )  # On matrix third <- sfGrowthLPD(dat,   MPD = MPD,   Temp = c(10, 25, 30),   time = 11 )

title: Reduction of L. monocytogenes due to smoking brined or dry-salted fish — sfSmoking
code: nLots <- 10 sizeLot <- 5 rBrineMean <- 0.871 rBrineSd <- 0.807 rDrysaltMean <- 1.093 rDrysaltSd <- 0.532 saltingType <- rbinom(nLots, size = 1, prob = 0.5) saltingType <- ifelse(saltingType == 1, "brined", "salted") data <- list(   N = matrix(rpois(nLots * sizeLot, 25), nrow = nLots, ncol = sizeLot),   P = 0.05, ProbUnitPos = rep(0.05, nLots), saltingType = saltingType )  smokedfish <- sfSmoking(data,   rBrineMean = 0.871, rBrineSd = 0.807,   rDrysaltMean = 1.093, rDrysaltSd = 0.532 ) hist(smokedfish$N)
